name: Jessica AOSE
comment info:
The first graph illustrates the New York Times spelling bee game’s most difficult words, while the second graph depicts the more easily discoverable ones. The yellow bars on each graph indicate the percentage of words that each contestant was able to identify and correctly spell. 

A noticeable trend emerged when analyzing these graphs: shorter, more common words that are frequently encountered in daily life were associated with a significantly higher success, with an average of 98% participants correctly identifying four-letter common words. In contrast, a mere 16% of individuals managed to identify the longer, less common, and more difficult words.  

This intriguing pattern poses the question to consider whether age might be a factor in an individual’s ability in this game and can even be generalized to the influence of age on an individual’s ability to recognize varying difficulty of words. My hypothesis is that older adults, having been exposed to more verbiage throughout their lifetime, might find it less challenging to decipher longer, less common words due to their broader range of vocabulary. 

The relevance of this observation does extend to my personal life and community involvement, since my father is an avid player of the New York Times spelling bee game. 

Title: “When spelling BEES run out of juice”

name: Katherine H
comment info:
The New York Times has become not only known for being a top contending news outlet but also for its online games. The Spelling Bee, a daily challenge in which players recieve a series of seven letters and must find as many word combinations as possible, has become one of the most played NYT games. This graph shows the percentage of players that discover easier versus harder words during the daily challenges from September 23rd to the 29th. Between 98% to 99% of players spelled the top 10 easiest words. Nine out of these ten words contain four letters, with "whipping" being the exception. As for the top ten hardest words, the percentages range from 16%, the number 1 hardest word “trigram”, to 39%, the tenth hardest word “grammarian”. I wonder why certain words, such as “clade”, are harder for people to spell. While it is not necessarily a word one hears every day, it is not a complex word to write. My community, and surrounding regions in New Jersey, is known for an amazing education system both public and private. Throughout my schooling, many of my teachers have been keen on the usage of vocabulary. So, I wonder how well I, and the other students in my community, would perform on the Spelling-Bee. Would a high percentage of us be able to reach the hardest word? Within the classroom, games such as Spelling Bee could be a fun way for students to improve their spelling and vocab abilities. 


This "Spelling Bee" Means Serious BEEs-ness!

Community Relevance: This observation is relevant to my school community because while most people would be able to guess the four-letter words, they might struggle with longer words.
